what: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
title: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
text: Get Events Evaluation State Variable

title: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
code: eventsByState(   timestamps,   states,   eventSeparationTime,   signalWidth,   in.state = 1,   out.state = 0 )

title: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
text: timestamps vector timestamps (POSIXct) states vector state values element corresponds one timestamp timstamps. state value given .state) corresponding times considered lying within event. state value given .state) corresponding times considered lying event. values neither values given .state .state, respectively, corresponding timestamps considered either belong event , depending previous clear state ("" "") sequence states. eventSeparationTime meaning hsEvents signalWidth see description hsEvents .state value states indicating state "event". Default: 1 .state value states indicating state "event". Default: 0

title: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
text: event characteristics (begin, end, duration, ...) data frame,   returned hsEvents

title: Get Events by Evaluation of a State Variable — eventsByState
code: # Generate random timestamps starttime <- as.POSIXct("2015-03-12 10:51")      n <- 100 timestamps <- seq(starttime, by = 60, length.out = n) values <- rnorm(n)    # Give values above 1 the state "in" and values below -1 the state "out" states <- rep("", times = n) states[values > 1] <- "in" states[values < -1] <- "out"    # Generate the events events <- eventsByState(   timestamps, states, eventSeparationTime = 5 * 60, in.state = "in",    out.state = "out", signalWidth = 60 )    # Prepare a vector of colours col <- rep("black", length(states)) col[states == "in"] <- "green" col[states == "out"] <- "red"    # Plot the values, the threshold lines and a legend graphics::plot(timestamps, values, type = "l", ylim = c(-5, 5)) points(timestamps, values, col = col)    graphics::abline(h = c(1, -1), lty = 2)    legend(   "topright", bty = "n", legend = c("in", "out"), col = c("green", "red"),     pch = 1, bg = "white", horiz = TRUE )    # Plot the event borders ganttPlotEvents(events, add = TRUE, y1 = -5, y2 = 4)

title: Changes in Value Vector to Events — eventsOnChange
text: Per default (numberOnly = FALSE) data frame returned   many rows “events” found vector x. long   value x change one index next,    assumed belong event. value changes, new event    begins. result data frame event represented iBeg  iEnd indices first last element,    respectively, x build event. numberOnly    TRUE number “events” returned, one plus number   changes value x first last element.

title: Changes in Value Vector to Events — eventsOnChange
code: eventsOnChange(c(1,2,2,3,4,4,4,5)) #>   iBeg iEnd #> 1    1    1 #> 2    2    3 #> 3    4    4 #> 4    5    7 #> 5    8    8    # Ouput: list of five events, i.e. there are four changes of  #        the value in the given vector. # #   iBeg iEnd # 1    1    1 # 2    2    3 # 3    4    4 # 4    5    7 # 5    8    8    eventsOnChange(c(1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5), numberOnly = TRUE) ## 5 (events) #> [1] 5

title: Example Events — exampleEvents
code: exampleEvents(   signalWidth = 60,   eventSeparationTime = 60 * signalWidth,   from = "2015-06-11",   to = "2015-06-12",   signalDensity = 0.01,   ... )

title: Example Events — exampleEvents
text: signalWidth see description hsEvents eventSeparationTime see description evtSepTime hsEvents first day character string format yyyy-mm-dd last day character string format yyyy-mm-dd signalDensity fraction timestamps full sequence timestamps selected randomly sequence treated "signals" contributing event. Default: 0.01, .e. one percent full sequence timestamps randomly selected, ordered passed hsEvents groups "signal" timestamps events ... arguments passed hsEvents

title: Example Events — exampleEvents
code: events <- exampleEvents()    # Calculate event durations manually dur <- as.integer(events$tEnd) - as.integer(events$tBeg) + hsSigWidth(events)    # All durations should be equal to the durations given in column "dur" all(dur == events$dur)  #> [1] TRUE    # All pauses after event i should be equal to the pauses before event i+1 all(events$pBefore[-1] == events$pAfter[-nrow(events)]) #> [1] TRUE

title: Filter Events with Statistics — filterEventsWithStatistics

title: Filter Events with Statistics — filterEventsWithStatistics
text: eventData eventData one time series, returned one list element getEventsWithStatistics. durationThreshold duration seconds needs exceeded (durationComparisonOperator == "gt") reached (durationComparisonOperator == "ge") duration rain events. Default: 0 durationComparisonOperator Operator applied comparing duration events durationThreshold. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt" sumThreshold value needs exceeded (sumComparisonOperator == "gt") reached (sumComparisonOperator == "ge") 'sum' values within events. Default: 0 sumComparisonOperator Operator applied comparing 'sum' values within events sumThreshold. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt"

code: ganttPlotEvents(   events,   add = FALSE,   y1 = 1,   y2 = y1 + 1,   xlim = NULL,   ylim = c(min(y1), max(y2)),   col = "black",   density = 5,   showLabels = TRUE,   eventLabels = rownames(events),   yLabel = (y1 + y2)/2,   type = "rectangle",   title = "",   leftMargin = 0.2,   xlab = "Time",   cex = 0.8,   indicate = NULL,   indicationColour = "red",   bandheight = 0.1,   alternating = FALSE,   adj = 0.5,   ... )

title: Gantt-like Diagram to plot Event's Time Extension — ganttPlotEvents
text: events event list retrieved hsEvents. Required columns: tBeg (begin event) tEnd (end event), class POSIXt add TRUE, event boxes added current plot, otherwise new plot generated y1 lower coordinates event boxes y2 upper coordinates event boxes xlim x limits. NULL (default) limits chosen events fit plot ylim y limits col colour shading lines density density shading lines showLabels TRUE, event boxes labelled row names events eventLabels labels given events. Default: rownames(events) yLabel y-position labels, labels shown type one c("rectange", "vertical") title title plotted left event rectangles leftMargin left margin (title printed) fraction range total time interval spanned events xlab x axis label cex character expansion factor indicate indices events indicated different color (indicationColuor) indicationColour colour used indication, default: "red"  extension factor labels (event numbers) bandheight passed addLabels alternating passed addLabels adj passed text plotting event labels ... arguments passed rect segments

title: Begin/End Relations between Events — getEventRelations
text: relations begin end events

title: Begin/End Relations between Events — getEventRelations
code: getEventRelations(   events,   referenceName,   partnerName,   parallelEventInfo = NULL,   dbg = TRUE )

title: Begin/End Relations between Events — getEventRelations
text: events list event lists (data frame), e.g. returned  getEventsWithStatisticsForMultipleSeries referenceName name column parallelEventInfo containing numbers events events column partnerName compared. partnerName name column parallelEventInfo containing numbers events compared events column  partnerName. parallelEventInfo data frame returned getParallelEventsInfo. NULL, events must specified. dbg TRUE, debug messages shown.

title: Begin/End Relations between Events — getEventRelations
code: # Load example data set containing a list of rain events at different gauges data(rainEvents)    cat(sprintf(   "Event lists available for: %s\n",     paste(names(rainEvents), collapse = ", ") )) #> Event lists available for: BlnX, BlnIX, BlnXI, Wil, Wila, Kar, ZhlI, StgI, Mal, Wit, ReiI    # How are rain events in BlnX related to rain events in Wil? eventRelations <- getEventRelations(   events = rainEvents,    referenceName = "BlnX",    partnerName = "Wil" ) #> referenceEventNumber: 1 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 2 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 3 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 4 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 5 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 6 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 7 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 8 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 9 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 10 #> No partner event at Wil found for event10 at BlnX #> referenceEventNumber: 11 -> 1  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 12 -> 2  partner events found. #> referenceEventNumber: 13 #> No partner event at Wil found for event13 at BlnX #> referenceEventNumber: 14 #> No partner event at Wil found for event14 at BlnX #> referenceEventNumber: 15 #> No partner event at Wil found for event15 at BlnX #> referenceEventNumber: 16 #> No partner event at Wil found for event16 at BlnX    # Let's have a look at the output eventRelations #>    event1 event2 beginRelation endRelation #> 1       1      2  beginsBefore   endsAfter #> 2       2      3   beginsAfter  endsBefore #> 3       3      4  beginsBefore   endsAfter #> 4       4      5  beginsBefore   endsAfter #> 5       5      6   beginsAfter   endsAfter #> 6       6      7  beginsBefore      endsAt #> 7       7      8      beginsAt  endsBefore #> 8       8      9   beginsAfter      endsAt #> 9       9     10  beginsBefore   endsAfter #> 10     11     12  beginsBefore  endsBefore #> 11     12     13   beginsAfter  endsBefore #> 12     12     14   beginsAfter  endsBefore    # Example 1: partner events that are fully containing the reference events isContaining <- eventRelations$beginRelation == "beginsBefore" &  eventRelations$endRelation == "endsAfter"    # The following table relates numbers of "partner" events (event2) to numbers # of "reference" events (event1) for each case in which a reference event is # fully contained in a partner event. containing <- eventRelations[isContaining, ]    # Let's check this graphically:    # Define plot matrix of two rows and one column old.par <- graphics::par(mfrow = c(2, 1))    ganttPlotEvents(   events = rainEvents$BlnX[],    indicate = containing$event1,    ylim = c(1, 2.8),    title = "BlnX",   indicationColour = "blue"   )    ganttPlotEvents(   rainEvents$Wil,    indicate = containing$event2,    add = TRUE,    y1 = 1.8,    title = "Wil" )    graphics::title("Events at Wil (red), fully containing events at BlnX (blue)")    # Example 2: partner events that are starting before the reference event starts # and ending before the reference event ends isOverlappingLeft <- eventRelations$beginRelation == "beginsBefore" &  eventRelations$endRelation == "endsBefore"    overlappingLeft <- eventRelations[isOverlappingLeft, ]    # Again, check this graphically: ganttPlotEvents(   events = rainEvents$BlnX[],    indicate = overlappingLeft$event1,    ylim = c(1, 2.8),    title = "BlnX",   indicationColour = "blue"   )    ganttPlotEvents(   rainEvents$Wil,    indicate = overlappingLeft$event2,    add = TRUE,    y1 = 1.8,    title = "Wil" )    graphics::title(paste(   "Events at Wil (red), starting before the start and ending before",   "the end\nof the events at BlnX (blue)" ))     # Reset graphical parameters graphics::par(old.par)

title: Get Events — getEvents
text: Get Events

title: Get Events — getEvents
code: getEvents(   rainData,   seriesName,   signalThreshold = 0,   signalComparisonOperator = "gt",   eventSeparationTime = 6 * 3600,   eventSeparationOperator = "gt",   signalWidth = NA,   column.time = names(rainData)[1] )

title: Get Events — getEvents
text: rainData data frame time stamps first column rain heights (intensities) remaining columns seriesName Column name rainData representing time series analysed. signalThreshold Value needs exceeded (signalComparisonOperator == "gt") reached (signalComparisonOperator == "ge") rain heights (intensities) order counted "signal". Default: 0 signalComparisonOperator Operator applied comparing rain values signalThreshold. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt". eventSeparationTime Time difference seconds needs exceeded (eventSeparationOperator == "gt") reached  (eventSeparationOperator == "ge") two consecutive signals order let signals belong two distinct events. Otherwise signals assumed belong one event. Default: 6*3600 = six hours. eventSeparationOperator Operator applied comparing time differences consecutive signals eventSeparationTime. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt". signalWidth signal width (= length time interval represented one row rainData) seconds column.time name column containing time. Default: Name first column

Default: 0 signalComparisonOperator Operator applied comparing rain values signalThreshold. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt" eventSeparationOperator passed getEvents functions passed getEventStatistics signalWidth passed getEvents

Maximal allowed time difference two consecutive timestamps within event. signalWidth “signal width” seconds. Length time interval one timestamp representing, e.g. \(5*60 = 300\) timestamp respresents time interval five minutes (e.g. time series  recorded five minute time scale). parameter needed  calculate event durations. signalThreshold value needs exceeded (signalComparisonOperator == "gt") reached (signalComparisonOperator == "ge") rain heights (intensities) order counted "signal". Default: 0 signalComparisonOperator Operator applied comparing rain values signalThreshold. Must one "gt" (greater ) "ge" greater equal. Default: "gt"

what: number timestamps according to event information — hsEventNumber

text: numbering timestamps according event information

title: number timestamps according to event information — hsEventNumber
code: hsEventNumber(   tstamps,   events,   eventNumbers = seq_len(nrow(events)),   commaSeparated = FALSE )

title: number timestamps according to event information — hsEventNumber
text: tstamps vector timestamps events event information returned hsEvents eventNumbers optional vector event numbers many elements rows tstamps. Default: seq_len(nrow(events)) commaSeparated timestamps taht belong one event, default behaviour (commaSeparated = FALSE) function return list list element vector integer numbers representing numbers events corresponding timestamps belong. commaSeparated = TRUE, list event numbers converted vector character element text string one event number separated comma. E.g. c("1", "1,2", "2") returned first timestamp belongs event 1, second event 1 2, third event 2.

title: Timestamp differences to events — hsEvents
text: Creates events vector tseries timestamps based time  differences consecutive timestamps tseries.

title: Timestamp differences to events — hsEvents
code: hsEvents(   tseries,   evtSepTime,   signalWidth,   tUnit = "s",   pause = TRUE,   evtSepOp = "gt",   dbg = FALSE,   check.sorting = FALSE )

title: Timestamp differences to events — hsEvents
text: tseries vector containing sorted list timestamps. evtSepTime “event separation time” seconds. Maximal allowed time difference two consecutive timestamps within event. signalWidth “signal width” seconds. Length time interval one timestamp representing, e.g. \(5*60 = 300\) timestamp respresents time interval five minutes (e.g. time series recorded five minute time scale). parameter needed calculate event durations. tUnit time unit event duration event pauses pause TRUE, pauses events calculated evtSepOp event separation operator, either "gt" "ge". evtSepOp = "gt" (default) events separated time differences two consecutive timestamps greater evtSepTime. evtSepOp = "ge" events separated time differences two consecutive timestamps greater equal evtSepTime. dbg TRUE, debug messages shown. check.sorting TRUE, checked whether timestamps given tseries sorted program stops case.

title: Timestamp differences to events — hsEvents
text: data frame columns iBeg iEnd indicating first   last index event tseries vector, tBeg  tEnd indicating first last timestamp event dur  indicating event duration seconds.

title: Are there overlapping Events? — overlapping
text: Check event list overlaps (begin one event end    previous event)

title: Are there overlapping Events? — overlapping
Are there overlapping Events? — overlapping
text: events event list returned hsEvents

title: Are there overlapping Events? — overlapping
text: TRUE overlapping events, otherwise FALSE

title: Are there overlapping Events? — overlapping
code: events <- kwb.event::exampleEvents()    # The example events do not overlap overlapping(events) #> [1] FALSE    # The order of the events (here reverse order) does not matter overlapping(events[nrow(events):1, ]) #> [1] FALSE    # Put the begin of the second event before the end of the last event events$tBeg[2] <- mean(c(events$tBeg[1], events$tEnd[1]))    # Now there are overlapping events! overlapping(events) #> [1] TRUE

title: Example rain events — rainEvents
text: Example lists rain events observed different rain gauges.

title: Example rain events — rainEvents
Example rain events — rainEvents
text: List eleven data frames represents list rain  events. data frame columns tBeg (first timestamp),  tEnd (last timestamp), dur (duration minutes), pBefore  (duration dry period event minutes), pAfter (duration  dry period event minutes), event (event number),  max (maximum rain intensity mm/5min), mean (mean rain  intensitiy mm/5min), min (minimum rain intensity mm/5min),  sum (rain height mm). data frame attributes assigned contain information parameters applied event creation process.
